extraction_notes.notes: Fresh extraction for variability test Run 04

evidence.content: Dataset of 773 burial mounds from TRAP pedestrian survey
evidence.verbatim_quote: In this study we used a dataset of 773 mounds, collected by TRAP during 2009–2011 field survey in the Kazanlak Valley, Bulgaria
After image augmentation, the model reported good learning and model fit (F1 = 0.87)

evidence.content: First run: 12.8% of tagged tiles contained actual mounds
evidence.verbatim_quote: Nevertheless, only 19 out of 148 tiles (12.8%) tagged by the model with at least a 60% chance of having a mound actually contained one
The 19 true-positive tiles contained 38 mounds (1–9 mounds per tile), out of 773 in the study area (4.9%)
Some 129 of the tagged tiles (87.1%) were false positives
Undetected mounds were located in 381 tiles... out of 400 tiles that actually contained mounds, a false negative rate of 95.3%

evidence.content: Second run F1 score declined to 0.62
evidence.verbatim_quote: The second model's performance declined to an F1 score of 0.62

evidence.content: Second run detected only 21 of 773 mounds (2.7%)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Validation revealed that only 21 of 773 mounds (2.7%) were detected, while 752 mounds (97.3%) remained undetected
The remaining 273 of 288 tiles were false positives (94.8%)
The undetected 752 mounds lay in 384 tiles... out of 399 tiles that actually contained mounds, a false negative rate of 96.2%
Developing our CNN model required approximately 135 person-hours from conceptualisation and experiments to validation and documentation

evidence.content: Model selected bright lines and edges rather than round shapes
evidence.verbatim_quote: Overall, the model seemed to select bright lines and edges (forest, roads), rather than round shapes more likely to represent mounds

evidence.content: 249 clearly visible mounds used for second run training
evidence.verbatim_quote: In the 2022 run, we selected 249 cutouts where a mound was discernible with the naked eye

evidence.content: Study area covered 85 sq km with 600 sq km of available imagery
evidence.verbatim_quote: Although we had 600 sq km of imagery, all data for CNN model training and validation came from the 85 sq km TRAP study area within it

evidence.content: Model failed to detect largest mounds despite clear visibility to humans
evidence.verbatim_quote: The greatest surprise was that the model failed to detect the largest mounds in the valley. These round, symmetrical features stand out against surrounding agricultural fields, and are crystal clear to any human viewer

evidence.content: Model flagged water surface as containing mounds
evidence.verbatim_quote: Furthermore, the model flagged parts of the reservoir as a mound with >60% probability, despite the homogeneous water surface

claims.content: Self-reported ML success rates were misleadingly high
claims.verbatim_quote: Validation of results against field data showed that self-reported success rates were misleadingly high, and that the model was misidentifying most features

claims.content: Pre-trained CNN struggles with varied features in heterogeneous landscapes
claims.verbatim_quote: Our attempt to deploy a pre-trained CNN demonstrates the limitations of this approach when it is used to detect varied features of different sizes within a heterogeneous landscape

claims.content: Filtered training data (visible mounds) produced worse results
claims.verbatim_quote: Counterintuitively, the model provided with training data selected for highly visible mounds (rather than all mounds) performed worse

claims.content: External validation with field data essential for CNN archaeological workflows
claims.verbatim_quote: The model has detected incidental features rather than the mounds themselves, making external validation with field data an essential part of CNN workflows

claims.content: Manual approaches may be more efficient for some archaeological applications
claims.verbatim_quote: The degree of manual intervention required... is so significant that it raises the question of whether it would be more efficient to identify all of the mounds manually

claims.content: Model detected background features rather than target features
claims.verbatim_quote: Models have been observed to predict class membership based on incidental background features in the periphery of the tiles that happen to accompany the target phenomenon in the centre

claims.content: ML archaeological literature exhibits publication bias
claims.verbatim_quote: The overwhelmingly positive tone of these papers likely indicates a certain degree of 'publication bias', where positive results are more likely to be published than negative

claims.content: Negative training data is critically important
claims.verbatim_quote: It may be counterintuitive, but care in creating the NOT MOUND tiles is as – if not more – important than the MOUND tiles

claims.content: Both model runs failed to identify burial mounds effectively
claims.verbatim_quote: Indeed, both models failed to identify burial mounds in our study area

claims.content: Fixed tile approach creates problems for variable feature sizes
claims.verbatim_quote: The training data with the smallest mounds leaves a lot of non-target pixels in the tile (ca. 98%), while introducing other repeating and prominent features that confuse the classifier

claims.content: High false positives and negatives demonstrate low-touch approach failure
claims.verbatim_quote: The high number of both false negatives and false positives demonstrated that our use of a low-touch approach – a pre-trained model plus sufficient but minimally curated training data – did not work

claims.content: Researchers need cost and failure information for informed ML adoption decisions
claims.verbatim_quote: We reiterate the call in that paper for researchers to publish the challenges, costs, and resourcing requirements alongside results – including for serious but failed attempts

claims.content: Additional curation of training data did not improve performance
claims.verbatim_quote: Overall, despite additional curation of the training data, the second run was even less successful than the first

implicit_arguments.content: Transfer learning success in simpler contexts does not guarantee success in complex archaeological applications
implicit_arguments.reconstructed_from: Comparison to successful Siberian applications implies homogeneity is key factor

implicit_arguments.content: Self-reported metrics without external validation are insufficient for ML evaluation
implicit_arguments.reconstructed_from: Contrast between F1 scores and field validation demonstrates inadequacy of internal metrics

implicit_arguments.content: Resource and time requirements should be standard in ML publications
implicit_arguments.reconstructed_from: Explicit statement that such reporting is rare implies it should be standard
Paper explicitly positions itself as cautionary tale, implying value of publishing failures

research_designs.description: Two-run comparison of training data selection strategies

variables.independent: Training data composition (all 773 mounds vs 249 visible mounds)

components.controls: Same model architecture, imagery, validation approach

research_designs.description: External validation against field-verified ground truth
Analysis of 70 ML archaeological remote sensing publications

methods.name: TRAP pedestrian survey
methods.description: Systematic field survey recording burial mounds with GPS coordinates, dimensions, and preservation status

methods.name: Transfer learning CNN
methods.description: Pre-trained ResNet-50 with additional training on MOUND/NOT MOUND image cutouts

methods.name: Spatial validation
methods.description: GIS intersection of predicted tiles with ground-truth mound points

methods.name: Literature review
methods.description: Systematic search and classification of ML archaeological remote sensing publications

methods.name: Image preprocessing
methods.description: Fusion of IKONOS panchromatic and multispectral bands, tiling into 150x150 pixel cutouts

protocols.name: TRAP mound recording protocol
protocols.description: GPS location, height/diameter measurement, preservation assessment using Likert scale and Wildesen classification

protocols.name: Training data preparation
protocols.description: Generate 150x150m cutouts from mound centroids, apply augmentation (flip, rotation), split 70:20:10

protocols.name: CNN training
protocols.description: Train ResNet-50 on MOUND/NOT MOUND cutouts with data augmentation to counter overfitting

protocols.name: Validation protocol
protocols.description: Select predictions >60%, create 150m polygons, intersect with ground truth points

protocols.name: Literature search
protocols.description: Web of Science topic search with manual review of relevance
